abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Highway Project
            for Nepal was satisfactory. The project met its immediate
            objectives. It has begun to strengthen the institutional
            capacity of the Borrower and private sector. Sustainability
            is uncertain at this time. Both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, maintenance effectiveness needs to
            be dramatically improved to ensure sustainability of road
            improvements. The most critical immediate challenge is to
            ensure that available maintenance resources are effectively
            and systematically used for highest-priority needs. Second,
            particular attention to drain clearing, river training
            works, and road repairs before and during the monsoon season
            can reduce the susceptibility to flood damage. Third, there
            is a need to improve procurement processing, customs
            clearance, and inter-ministerial coordination in DOR and
            HMGN to permit timely and effective response to road
            improvement needs and reduce the costs of works
            implementation. Lastly, the involvement of the DOR staff in
            project preparation should be expanded and encourage in the
            future for effective implementation.
